content.title: Theoretical Minimum Energy
content.abstract: Analysis of theoretical minimum energy values, distinguishing between zero-point energy (vacuum), photon energies (which can be arbitrarily small), and the question of whether a minimum energy quantum exists.

theoretical_minimum.ground_state: Zero-point energy E₀ = ℏω/2 for each mode
theoretical_minimum.photon_energy: E = hν (can be arbitrarily small as ν→0)
theoretical_minimum.status: MIXED - depends on what you're asking

different_contexts.note: Zero-point fluctuations exist but don't contribute to measurable energy differences
For a given frequency, this is the minimum. But frequency can be arbitrarily low.

different_contexts.minimum: Neutrino mass < 0.8 eV/c² (sum of three < 0.12 eV)
different_contexts.note: Lightest massive particle; photon and gluon are exactly massless

different_contexts.minimum: Ground state energy, e.g., E₁ = -13.6 eV for hydrogen
different_contexts.note: System cannot go below ground state

can_energy_be_arbitrarily_small.for_photons: Yes - ν can approach 0, so E = hν → 0
can_energy_be_arbitrarily_small.example: Ultra-low frequency radio: ν = 1 Hz → E = 6.6×10⁻³⁴ J
can_energy_be_arbitrarily_small.cosmic_limit: Photon with λ = observable universe: E ~ 10⁻⁵¹ J

zero_point_energy.total: Formally infinite (all modes); physical effects finite

quantum_gravity_considerations.note: This is ENORMOUS, not a minimum

quantum_gravity_considerations.prediction: Some GUP formulations suggest minimum measurable energy
quantum_gravity_considerations.formula: E_min ~ ℏc/l_max where l_max is maximum position uncertainty

comparison_with_planck.insight: Planck energy is a scale of strong gravity, not a minimum
